Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing, Joshua Barousse, Chairperson, Mariel Caballero, Vice Chairperson, and Ramon Martinez of Measure G, Measure E and Measure I Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee
					 
SUBJECT:
Receive Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee’s 2012-2013 Bond Program Annual Report for Measures G, E and I
	 
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) has produced their Bond Program Annual Report for 2012-2013.  This Annual Report satisfies the requirement of Education Code Section 15278(a) for the Committee to inform the public concerning the expenditure of bond revenues, by actively reviewing and reporting on the proper expenditure of taxpayers’ money for school construction.  The Report will be distributed to the community in late August.
	 
The 2012-2013 Bond Program Annual Report will be presented to the Board by CBOC Chairperson Joshua Barousse, Vice Chairperson Mariel Caballero, and member Ramon Martinez.
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the 2012 - 2013 Annual CBOC Report for Measures G, E, and I.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  9.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
						 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m., regarding the NHU Foundation’s Request for Material Revision to the Term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy Academy Charter
		 
		 
On August 21, 2014, the Board of Trustees of the East Side Union High School District will hold a public hearing during the Board’s Regular Meeting. The purpose of the public hearing is to solicit recommendations and comments from the public regarding the material revision to the term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter approved by East Side Union High School Board of Trustees on August 23, 2013, “for a term of 2 years to end on June 30, 2015.”
		 
The NHU Foundation did not open the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy in fall 2014. The NHU Foundation is requesting to delay the opening of the school to fall 2015 and extend the term of the charter by one year. The term of the charter would end on June 30, 2016.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold public hearing to solicit recommendations and comments from the public regarding the material revision to the term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  9.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Action on Request for Material Revision to the Term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy Charter
			 
                                                                                                
I. Brief Introduction and Summary
			 
On August 23, 2013, the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees (Board) approved the charter petition for B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy (BRC), granting the NHU Foundation permission to operate BRC within the boundaries of the East Side Union High School District, located in San Jose, California. The Board granted the NHU Foundation for BRC, a term of two years to end on June 30, 2015. BRC was scheduled to open fall 2014.
			 
On August 6, 2014, the East Side Union High School District received a letter (Attachment A) and "revised" three-year budget (Attachment B) from the NHU Foundation informing the District of its intention to delay the opening of BRC until fall 2015. The request for a delay in opening requires a material revision to the term of the charter. The original term of the charter was for two years with an ending date of June 30, 2015. The NHU Foundation is requesting to extend the term of the charter by one year, to end on June 30, 2016. The reason given by the NHU Foundation for the one-year delay is to have "more time to plan and recruit students."
			 
II.Standard for Review/Denial Authorization
			 
Pursuant to Education Code § 47607 (a) (1), the Board must consider whether to approve the material revision. Education Code § 47607 (a) (2) requires that “material revisions of charters” are to “be governed by the standards and criteria in Section 47605.” Therefore, if the Board should decide to deny NHU’s material revision request for BRC, then the Board must make “written factual findings,” specific to the particular petition, setting forth specific facts to support one or more of the following findings:
			 
(1)  The charter school presents an unsound educational program for the pupils to be enrolled in the charter school.
(2)  The petitioners are demonstrably unlikely to successfully implement the program set forth in the petition.
(3)  The petition does not contain the number of signatures required by subdivision (a).
(4)  The petition does not contain an affirmation of each of the conditions described in subdivision (d).
(5)  The petition does not contain reasonably comprehensive descriptions of all of the required elements.
			 
Findings #1, #3, #4 and #5 would not be applicable.  If the Board decides to deny the request to delay the opening of BRC by one year to August 2015, it must make “written factual findings” with respect to Finding #2.  
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
The Administration recommends that the Board approve the material revision request to the term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter to extend by one year the opening to fall 2015. The two-year term of the charter would end on June 30, 2016.
items.item_recommendation: The Administration recommends that the Board approve the material revision request to the term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter to extend by one year the opening to fall 2015. The two-year term of the charter would end on June 30, 2016.

FROM:

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding California School Boards Association (CSBA) Candidate Nominations for Directors-at-Large:  Asian Pacific Islander and Hispanic
	 
		 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for Directors-at-Large:  Asian Pacific Islander and Hispanic. The election will take place at CSBA's Delegate Assembly meeting in San Francisco, California, on December 14, 2014.  Nominations for Directors-at-Large must be made by a CSBA board member and the nominee must be board member from a CSBA member district or county office of education.  Directors-at-Large serve a two-year term and take office immediately upon the close of the Association's Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in December.
		 
The Board is requested to submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large:  Asian Pacific Islander and Hispanic
		 
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
		It is recommended that the Board of Trustees submit nominations to CSBA for Directors-at-Large: Asian Pacific Islander and Hispanic.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.04
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding African American Student Support Services
All incoming 9th grade African American students were actively recruited to enroll in the Summer Bridge Program
Staff called all students and made home visits if the phone numbers were incorrect 
Follow-up contact was made if the students did not show up
		 
Per the Board Members request, below is the specific support that the District  has committed to provide for the 2014 - 2015 school year:
		 
District African America Freshman Orientation
Invitations were sent to all incoming African American freshmen
TeleParent messages were sent
Over 50 home visits were made
Each African American student will have an Individual Learning Plan (ILP) developed by September 30th and at the end of each semester
		 
The District will work with each site to establish Black Student Unions at sites that currently do not have one and strengthen the existing ones
		 
The District is piloting an intervention program that provides wrap around services at Mount Pleasant High School and Oak Grove High School for the upcoming school year.
Mount Pleasant:
Ms. Robinson will be teaching a culturally relevant curriculum as one of her teaching periods and will provide support services with a release period
Oak Grove:
Contracting with Bay Area Tutoring Association (BATA) to provide academic support services as well as teach the culturally relevant curriculum on Mondays and Wednesdays.
BATA will be at Oak Grove High School providing academic tutoring on Tuesdays and Thursdays as part of the Santa Clara County Mental Health Grant with Unity Care

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary Education
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Second Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering April 1, 2014,  through June 30, 2014, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from April 1, 2014 through June 30, 2014.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical Funds as Appropriate
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Second Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering April 1, 2014 through June 30, 2014, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Provisional Internship Permit Requests for Certificated Employees
	 
	 
Pursuant to State mandate, the Governing Board must approve provisional internship permit requests allowing the district to employ and assign teacher(s) or administrator(s) who do not hold appropriate credential authorization.
	 
The Provisional Internship Permit (PIP) was created in response to the phasing out of emergency permits and became effective on July 1, 2006.  It allows an employing agency to hire an individual who has not yet met the subject matter competence requirement needed to enter an internship program.
	 
The district is requesting approval of the following provisional internship permit requests for the 2014-2015 school year.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Months of June 2014 and July 2014
							 
							 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the months of June 2014, and July 2014, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment of Goods and Services adopted in May 2009.  The Policy states that, "The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting."  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval on issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the "transparency" of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies. 
							 
Fiscal Impact:
Not Applicable
							 
Funding Source:
Not Applicable

It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the warrant register as presented.

In accordance with the Board’s direction and authorization, the parties have now signed and entered into a Facilities Use Agreement, which Administration presents for the Board’s ratification.

Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment

As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and Authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
